title: 113_hr4676
content: The Act titled "Medicaid Physician Self-Referral Act of 2014" makes adjustments to restrictions on self-referral under Medicaid. The "Medicaid Physician Self-Referral Act of 2014" repeals restrictions on self-referral for federal funds and requires states to restrict self-referral in their Medicaid plans. No payment can be made for designated health services based on a physician's referral if the physician or an immediate family member benefits. The "Medicaid Physician Self-Referral Act of 2014" prohibits physicians from referring Medicaid designated health services if they have a financial interest in the entity providing the service that would violate federal regulations. This includes ownership, investment interest, or compensation arrangements that do not comply with the law. The Act also applies subsections (f) and (g) of section 1877 to Medicaid providers similar to how it applies to providers under Medicare. The "Medicaid Physician Self-Referral Act of 2014" prohibits physicians from referring Medicaid designated health services if they have a financial interest that violates federal regulations. Violations of self-referral can result in false or fraudulent claims under the False Claims Act. Exceptions for violations of self-referral are limited to Medicaid providers. The "Medicaid Physician Self-Referral Act of 2014" prohibits physicians from referring Medicaid designated health services if they have a financial interest that violates federal regulations. Violations can lead to false or fraudulent claims under the False Claims Act, with exceptions limited to Medicaid providers. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a protocol for health care providers to disclose violations of the Social Security Act as applied to Medicaid. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a protocol for health care providers to disclose violations of the Social Security Act as applied to Medicaid. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by the "Medicaid Physician Self-Referral Act of 2014" apply to items and services provided after the first day of the first calendar year following the enactment of the Act, with an exception for State legislation under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The State legislature's regular session begins after the enactment of this Act. In a 2-year legislative session, each year is considered a separate regular session.
